newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia says may not sign new rubber pact.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia says may not sign new rubber pact.

text.p: - Malaysia said on Monday it was unlikely to sign a new global rubber pact if Indonesia refused to withdraw its bid for the International Natural Rubber Organisation (INRO) executive director's post.
Primary Industries Minister Lim Keng Yaik said there would be no third International Natural Rubber Agreement (INRA III) if Malaysia did not sign the pact. The pact was agreed in Geneva last year.
The national news agency Bernama quoted Lim as saying the government would discuss the matter with Indonesian President Suharto who is due to visit Malaysia soon.
Speaking to reporters after opening a palm oil congress, Lim said: "Indonesia is sabotaging our bid... so I have to consider seriously whether or not to join INRA III.
"We made our bid known very early and yet the Indonesians have come in to counter bid us," Bernama quoted him as saying.
"It is a matter of principle and now it is our turn... How come they are denying it."
Malaysia says it is its turn to hold the executive director's post under an unofficial rotation scheme. But Indonesia has argued Malaysia already has the privilege of hosting the INRO secretariat.
INRO is made up of 23 major natural rubber consuming countries and six major producing nations. Three-quarters of the members have signed the new pact, now scheduled for ratification in 1997.
